--- title: CircuitPython_pico_pi_controller keywords: fastai sidebar: home_sidebar summary: "The `pico_pi_controller` module contains CircuitPython classes to manage multiple Raspberry Pi SBCs from a Raspberry Pi Pico, using i2c." description: "The `pico_pi_controller` module contains CircuitPython classes to manage multiple Raspberry Pi SBCs from a Raspberry Pi Pico, using i2c." nb_path: "00_core.ipynb" ---
{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

About

The classes in this module inherit from Adafruit's busio & adafruit_bus_device I2C classes for CircuitPython. busio is distributed with CircuitPython, and adafruit_bus_device is distributed with the CircuitPython Library Bundle.

Broadcom SoC hardware I2C is utilized both for the controlling MCU (the Pico) and the controlled SBCs (Raspberry Pi 4/3+/Zero). I2C baudrate is limited from the controller (the Pico) to reduce transmit/receive errors.

Controller programs may be written with hard-coded I2C peripheral addresses of connected SBCs (called 'devices' by these classes). Or, autodiscovery may be used so that devices may be added without changing software on the controller.

For example:

from pico_pi_controller import *

mycontroller = PPController()

mycontroller.addDevice('0x13') mycontroller.listdevices() </code>

This example will initialize I2C on the controller using the board defaults (I2C bus 1), retrieve host information & statistics from the SBC at I2C address 0x13, then return a list of device information.

Classes

{% raw %}

class UNDevice[source]

UNDevice(controller, device_address, *argv, **kwargs)

Represents an I2C peripheral device unidentified to a PPController

{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class PPDevice[source]

PPDevice(controller, device_address, *argv, **kwargs)

Represents an I2C peripheral device identified as a PPDevice and stores data from those hosts.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class PPController[source]

PPController(**kwargs)

Represents one of the system's I2C busses and tracks which I2C peripherals are PPDevices.
